dublin_core.dcvalue: This study examines a relations among technology use during sleep time sleep quality and depression anxiety and b time awake due to technology use Two hundred thirty six college students completed self report questionnaires and week long sleep diaries Results revealed that 47 percent of students reported night time waking to answer text messages and 40 percent to answer phone calls Regression analyses indicated that higher levels of technology use after the onset of sleep predicted poorer sleep quality and poorer sleep quality predicted symptoms of depression anxiety Finally sleep quality is a mediator between technology use after the onset of sleep and depression anxiety College students who have difficulty setting boundaries around technology use may be at increased risk for psychological health concerns
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T17:07:54Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2013-01-16
Sleep quality as a mediator between technology-related sleep quality, depression, and anxiety.
